div.div: Following are resources to help you support your childs learning at home so that previously learned skills are maintained. We recognize that your time is valuable and that you may not have time to teach your child. So rather than overwhelming you with too many options, we have identified a more limited number of resources. Just click on your child's grade for ideas. All the best to you and your family, and we hope to see you soon.

div.script:
$(document).ready(function () {
        var logConsole = function (str) {
            console.log(str);
        };
        if ($('#tabPortlet_474864 .divTabEdit').val() == "True") {
            var isModern = ('True');
            if(isModern.toLowerCase() == "true")
            {
                var tabObj = $('#tabPortlet_474864 ');
                var tabM = $('#ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl17_divTabs').attr('portlet') == 'tab';

                function activate() {
                    $(tabObj).scrollingTabs({                 
                        tabs: [{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl17_divTabs_0","title":"Pre-K","content":"
Reading
Read books to and with children at least 15 minutes twice a day.

• Use different voices for characters and add sound effects to bring the story to life. 

• Read the book the first time through for enjoyment

• During the second reading of the book, pause and ask your child questions about the story. Consider “what if” questions that allow them to think how characters might react differently if something changed in the storyline. Also ask them about how characters might feel. Sequencing events (what happened first, second, third) and predicting what happens next is also a favorite way to interact with a book.




Rhyming Activities
Choose a nursery rhyme or other poem from the resource links to read to and with your child. Call attention to words that rhyme, those that have the same ending sounds. Give your child a “shopping bag” to shop the room(s) for two items that rhyme. When child returns with items, say the names of the objects and decide together if they are rhyming words. Repeat for as long as child remains interested.

Writing

Set up a space with crayons, markers, and/or pencils with scrap paper for children to draw/illustrate favorite events from a story read to them for about 15 minutes a day. Ask children to describe the message or story they wrote.

Mathematics and Movement

    
Count out loud: 10 jumping jacks • 5 push ups • 5 squats • 5 sit ups • 5 jumps Repeat 2-3 times
    
Count out loud: Between activities or during TV commercials, get up and sing and dance while counting.
    
Oral counting to 30: Count to 30 while washing hands.
    
Shape hunt: Walk your child around the house and see how many circles, squares, rectangles, and triangles he/she can find. Example: the door is a rectangle.


 

Mathematics

    
Counting game:

    On folded pieces of scrap paper, write numerals 0–12. Place folded numerals inside a sock, basket, hat, bag, box, or other container. Ask child to take a folded paper out and look at the numeral without telling what numeral he/she has. Then, the child goes and brings that “many” toys or other objects for you to see. Child counts the toys/objects and shows you the numeral. Verify the quantity and numeral match-up. Repeat as long as child remains interested.
    
Addition and subtraction to 10: Create addition and subtraction story problems using buttons, toys, coins, socks, etc. For example, “4 socks are dirty and need to be washed and are in the basket. 2 more socks were added to the basket. How many socks need to be washed now?” Repeat as long as children are interested.
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl17_divTabs_1","title":"Kindergarten","content":"
Reading
We encourage all kindergarten children to spend at least 15-20 minutes a day reading.  This time can be broken into smaller amounts if this works best for you and your child.  Kindergarteners should be reading simple, patterned books that have supportive pictures and many familiar words.  Below, we have included resources for online reading if you find you need more books.


Read Aloud
Research shows that reading aloud with your child is a powerful way to help them understand how stories and books work and learn new vocabulary, as well as a wonderful way to spend time as a family!  We encourage all families to put time aside each day as read-aloud time.

Writing

 Ideally, we would like kindergarteners to write for about 10-15 minutes a day, five days a week. Again, we wish to maintain your child’s current writing skills, and this is best done through consistent, daily practice.  Your child may write about anything he/she wishes - a topic he/she is interested in, a story about something that happened to him/her, a list of his/her favorite things - the possibilities are endless!  A list of possible writing topics has also been included in the writing section below.  Look through them and select ones that you feel would be most appropriate and engaging for your child.



Writing topics for Kindergarten – Second Graders: 

    
Write a story using three of the of the following words: apple, train, elephant, paper, banjo.
    
What do you want to be when you grow up and why?
    
Who is your favorite character from a book you have read recently? What do you like most about that person?
    
Write about a time you felt really happy. What happened? What made you feel happy?
    
What are some of your favorite animals? What do you like about them?


Mathematics and Movement

    
Do jumping jacks as you count from 10 to 20 and back. Then count again.
    
Do counting squats.  Count down from 20 to 0 and back up.
    
Do arm swings as you count from 10 to as high as you can in one minute.
    
Do counting squats.  Count from 0 to 20 and back.
    
Do jumping jacks as you count up by tens to 100 and back down to 0.
    
Hop on one foot as you say all the partners to 5. 

    Ex.: (1 and 4) (2 and 3) (5 and 0) (4 and 1) etc...
    
Go on a shape scavenger hunt.

    Find as many rectangles, triangles, squares, hexagons as you can.
    
Measure the route from your bathroom to your bedroom.  
    
Walk heel to toe and count your steps.


Mathematics

    
Write a story problem for 2 + 3.
    
Go on a shape scavenger hunt.  
    
Find as many spheres, cylinders, cones, cubes.
    
Draw a picture to show 16.  Circle a group of ten.
    
Draw 4 balloons. Draw 10 more.  How many balloons did you draw?


Make 10 (Grades K-1)
Materials: 1 or 2 dice; a piece of paper

Directions: Object: Make 10 by rolling the dice.

One Die Version for Kindergarten:

    
One die is rolled.
    
Players try to shout out the number that needs to be added to the number to make the number a ten.
    
The number to make a ten becomes that players score for that round.
    
For example: If 3 is rolled, players would shout 7, because 3 and 7 makes 10. The first player to answer correctly earns 7 points.


Two Die Version for Grade 1:

    
Two dice are rolled.
    
Players must add or subtract to make 10.
    
For example: If two 6s are rolled, players would shout 2 because 6 + 6 = 12 and              12 – 2 = 10. 


Shake Those Pennies (Grades K-1)

Materials: Pennies

(The number of pennies needed depends on the number being practiced. For example, if you

are practicing sums for 10, you will need 10 pennies.)

Directions:

    
Shake your pennies in your hands or a cup then drop them on the table.
    
Say and/or write the two addition sentences that add together the heads and tails. (For example, if you see 7 heads and 3 tails, you would say or write 7 + 3 = 10 and 3 + 7 = 10.)
    
Challenge: Say four addition sentences instead of two. (For example, 10 = 7 + 3,  10 = 3 + 7,      7 + 3 = 10, and 3 + 7 = 10.)
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl17_divTabs_2","title":"First Grade","content":"
Reading
We encourage all first- grade children to spend at least 20 minutes a day reading. This time can be broken into smaller amounts if this works best for you and your child. Your first grader may be reading simple, patterned books that have supportive pictures and many familiar words or may be moving into simple chapter books. Below, we have included links to resources for online reading if you find you need more books.


Read Aloud
Research shows that reading aloud with your child is a powerful way to help them understand how stories and books work and learn new vocabulary, as well as a wonderful way to spend time as a family!  We encourage all families to put time aside each day as read-aloud time.


Writing
Ideally, we would like first graders to write for about 20 minutes a day, five days a week. Again, we wish to maintain your child’s current writing skills, and this is best done through consistent, daily practice.  Your child may write about anything he/she wishes - a topic he/she is interested in, a story about something that happened to him/her, a list of his/her favorite things - the possibilities are endless! A list of possible writing topics has also been included with the writing resources below. Look through them and select ones that you feel would be most appropriate and engaging for your child.

Writing topics for Kindergarten – Second Graders:

    
Write a story using three of the of the following words: apple, train, elephant, paper, banjo.
    
What do you want to be when you grow up and why?
    
Who is your favorite character from a book you have read recently? What do you like most about that person?
    
Write about a time you felt really happy. What happened? What made you feel happy?
    
What are some of your favorite animals? What do you like about them?


Mathematics and Movement

    
Do counting squats. Count from 45 to 60 and back.
    
Do jumping jacks as you count up by tens to 120 and back down to 0.
    
Do arm swings while counting down from 99 to 75 and back up.
    
Do jumping jacks as you count up by tens from 9 to 119.
    
Hop on one foot as you say all the partners to 10

    Ex.: (1 and 9) (2 and 8) (3 and 7) etc...
    
Write numbers starting at 10 to as high as you can in one minute. 

    Try to beat your score!
    
Make a graph of the types of fruits in your kitchen.  What did you find out?
    
Use real coins or draw coins to show as many ways to make 25 cents.


Mathematics

    
Write a story problem for 9 + 4.
    
Use quick tens and ones to draw 76.
    
Measure the steps from your bedroom to the kitchen, walking heel to toe. Then have a family member do the same thing. Compare.
    
Write all the related number sentences for 2, 8, 10
    
Choose a related fact of your choice and write all of the related number sentences. 


Make 10 (Grades K-1)

Materials: 1 or 2 dice; scratch paper

Directions: Object: Make 10 from the number rolled.

One Die Version for Kindergarten:

    
One die is rolled.
    
Players try to shout out the number that needs to be added to the number to make the number a ten.
    
The number to make a ten becomes that players score for that round.
    
For example: If 3 is rolled, players would shout 7, because 3 and 7 makes 10. The first player to answer correctly earns 7 points.


Two Die Version for Grade 1:

    
Two dice are rolled.
    
Players must add or subtract to make 10.
    
For example: If two 6s are rolled, players would shout 2 because 6 + 6 = 12 and 12 – 2 = 10. 


Shake Those Pennies (Grades K-1)

Materials: Pennies

(The number of pennies needed depends on the number being practiced. For example, if you

are practicing sums for 10, you will need 10 pennies.)

Directions:

    
Shake your pennies in your hands or a cup then drop them on the table.
    
Say and/or write the two addition sentences that add together the heads and tails. (For example, if you see 7 heads and 3 tails, you would say or write 7 + 3 = 10 and 3 + 7 = 10.)
    
Challenge: Say four addition sentences instead of two. (For example, 10 = 7 + 3, 10 = 3 + 7, 7 + 3 = 10, and 3 + 7 = 10.)


Salute (Grades 1-5)

Materials: At least 3 players, a deck of cards (with the jacks, queens, kings, aces and jokers removed)

Directions:

Grades 1-2 will add; Grades 3-5 will multiply.

    
There will be two players and 1 judge.
    
Deal an equal number of cards face down to all three players.
    
Player 1 and Player 2 flip a card (without looking) and place it on their forehead facing each other.
    
The judge will say the product/sum of the two cards.
    
The first player to announce THEIR card takes both cards.
    
Rotate roles and continue.
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl17_divTabs_3","title":"Second Grade","content":"
Reading
We encourage all second-grade children to spend at least 20 minutes a day reading.  This time can be broken into smaller amounts if this works best for you and your child.  Your second grader may be reading simple chapter books or may be moving into more complex chapter books.  Below, we have included a folder containing resources for online reading if you find you need more books.


Read Aloud
Research shows that reading aloud with your child is a powerful way to help them understand how stories and books work and learn new vocabulary, as well as a wonderful way to spend time as a family!  We encourage all families to put time aside each day as read-aloud time.

Writing
Ideally, we would like second graders to write for about 20 minutes a day, five days a week. Again, we wish to maintain your child’s current writing skills, and this is best done through consistent, daily practice.  Your child may write about anything he/she wishes - a topic he/she is interested in, a story about something that happened to him/her, a list of his/her favorite things - the possibilities are endless!  A list of possible writing topics has also been included in the second grade Writing Resources folder.  Look through them and select ones that you feel would be most appropriate and engaging for your child.

Writing topics for Kindergarten – Second Graders:

    
Write a story using three of the of the following words: apple, train, elephant, paper, banjo.
    
What do you want to be when you grow up and why?
    
Who is your favorite character from a book you have read recently? What do you like most about that person?
    
Write about a time you felt really happy. What happened? What made you feel happy?
    
What are some of your favorite animals? What do you like about them?


Mathematics and Movement

    
Do counting squats. 

    Count by 5’s from 0-50 and back down to 0.
    
Do jumping jacks as you count up by tens to 120 and back down to 0
    
Do counting squats. 

    Count by 100’s from 120-920 and back down to 120.
    
Hop on one foot as you count by fives from 5 to 40 and back.
    
Do arm swings as you count up by tens from 9 to 119 and back down to 0.
    
Alternate counting with a friend or family member by twos from 2 to 30 and back.
    
Make a graph of the types of fruits in your kitchen.  What did you find out from your graph?
    
Measure the route from your bathroom to your bedroom.  

    Walk heel to toe and count your steps.


Mathematics

    
Clock Diary

    Write about events happening during the day along with writing down the time they occurred.
    
Go on a shape scavenger hunt.  

    Find as many shapes as you can. Use tally marks to display your data.
    
Write a story problem for

    7 + ____ = 12.
    
Use real coins or draw coins to show as many ways to make a dollar as you can.


Final Countdown (Grades 2-4)

Materials: 2 dice, 1 piece of paper for each     player, a pencil for each player 

Directions for Grade 2:

(addition/subtraction)

    
Ask each player to write the number "99" at the top of their scratch paper.
    
Have the first player roll both dice and add them together to find the sum. 
    
Then, subtract the sum from their starting number of 99. After figuring out their result, they record the number remaining on their scratch paper. 
    
(For example: if they roll a 4 and 5,  4 + 5 = 9, 99 - 9 = 90. They would write 90.)
    
Have each player take a turn rolling the dice and computing their results.
    
The first player to get to zero wins!


Directions for Grades 3-4: (multiplication/subtraction)

    
Ask each player to write the number "399" at the top of their scratch paper.
    
Have the first player roll both dice and multiply them together to find the product. 
    
Then, subtract the product from their starting number of 399. After figuring out their result, they record the number remaining on their scratch paper. (For example: if they roll a 4 and 5,  4 x 5 = 20, 399 - 20 = 379. They would write 379.)
    
Have each player take a turn rolling the dice and computing their results.
    
The first player to get to zero wins!


Salute (Grades 1-5)

Materials: At least 3 players, a deck of cards (with the jacks, queens, kings, aces and jokers removed)

Directions:

Grades 1-2 will add; Grades 3-5 will multiply.

    
There will be two players and 1 judge.
    
Deal an equal number of cards face down to all three players.
    
Player 1 and Player 2 flip a card (without looking) and place it on their forehead facing each other.
    
The judge will say the product/sum of the two cards.
    
The first player to announce THEIR card takes both cards.
    
Rotate roles and continue.
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl17_divTabs_4","title":"Third Grade","content":"
Reading
We encourage all third-grade children to spend at least 20-30 minutes a day reading. This time can be broken into smaller amounts if this works best for you and your child. Your third grader may be reading simple chapter books or may be moving into chapter books that are more complex in terms of character development, themes, and ideas. Below, we have included links to resources for online reading if you find you need more books.


Read Aloud
Research shows that reading aloud with your child is a powerful way to help them understand how stories and books work, think about bigger and more complex themes and ideas in literature, and learn new vocabulary. Read-aloud is also a wonderful way to spend time as a family! We encourage all families to put time aside each day as read-aloud time.


Writing
Ideally, we would like third graders to write for about 20 minutes a day, five days a week. Again, we wish to maintain your child’s current writing skills, and this is best done through consistent, daily practice. Your child may write about anything he/she wishes - a topic he/she is interested in, a story about something that happened to him/her, a list of his/her favorite things - the possibilities are endless! A list of possible writing topics has also been included in the writing section below. Look through them and select ones that you feel would be most appropriate and engaging for your child. Encourage your child to apply what he/she knows about good writing at all times.


Writing topics for Third – Fifth Graders:

    
Do you have any siblings? Think about what it might mean to be a good brother or sister and write about it!
    
Make a list of questions to interview your parents or grandparents about what it was like when they were growing up as a kid. Then, ask them the questions and write about their answers!
    
You are in charge of writing a new radio show that is specifically made for kids to listen to! What topics do you have the announcers talk about? What music do you play? What products might you advertise?
    
Imagine if you are the principal of the school. What might you do differently? What things would you do that are the same? Write about it!
    
Every year over 8 billion plastic bottles and cans are thrown away. What are some things you can do to help encourage your family and friends to recycle?


Mathematics and Movement

    
Do jumping jacks as you count by twos from 20 to 100 and back from 100 to 20.
    
Do squats as you count by threes to 30 and back again.
    
Hop on one foot as you count by fours from 4 to 40 and back.
    
Do arm swings as you count by sixes from 6 to 60 and back.
    
Alternate counting with a friend or family member by sevens from 7 to 70 and back.
    
Jump forward and back as you count by eights from 8 to 80 and back.
    
Read the weight in grams of different food items in your kitchen. Round the weights to the nearest 10 or 100 grams.
    
Read a recipe. What fractions does the recipe use?


Mathematics

    
Draw and label a floor plan of your house.
    
Time how long it takes you to do a specific chore, like making the bed.  See if you can do it faster the next day.
    
Measure the side lengths of the room where you sleep in inches.  Then calculate the area.
    
Go on a shape scavenger hunt. 

    Find as many quadrilaterals in your neighborhood or house as you can.


Final Countdown (Grades 2-4)

Materials: 2 dice, 1 piece of paper for each player, a pencil for each player 

Directions for Grade 2:

(addition/subtraction)

    
Ask each player to write the number "99" at the top of their scratch paper.
    
Have the first player roll both dice and add them together to find the sum. 
    
Then, subtract the sum from their starting number of 99. After figuring out their result, they record the number remaining on their scratch paper. 
    
(For example: if they roll a 4 and 5, 4 + 5 = 9, 99 - 9 = 90. They would write 90.)
    
Have each player take a turn rolling the dice and computing their results.
    
The first player to get to zero wins!


Directions for Grades 3-4: (multiplication/subtraction)

    
Ask each player to write the number "399" at the top of their scratch paper.
    
Have the first player roll both dice and multiply them together to find the product. 
    
Then, subtract the product from their starting number of 399. After figuring out their result, they record the number remaining on their scratch paper. (For example: if they roll a 4 and 5, 4 x 5 = 20, 399 - 20 = 379. They would write 379.)
    
Have each player take a turn rolling the dice and computing their results.
    
The first player to get to zero wins!


Salute (Grades 1-5)

Materials: At least 3 players, a deck of cards (with the jacks, queens, kings, aces and jokers removed)

Directions:

Grades 1-2 will add; Grades 3-5 will multiply.

    
There will be two players and 1 judge.
    
Deal an equal number of cards face down to all three players.
    
Player 1 and Player 2 flip a card (without looking) and place it on their forehead facing each other.
    
The judge will say the product/sum of the two cards.
    
The first player to announce THEIR card takes both cards.
    
Rotate roles and continue.
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl17_divTabs_5","title":"Fourth Grade","content":"
Reading
We encourage all fourth-grade children to spend at least 30 minutes a day reading. This time can be broken into smaller amounts if this works best for you and your child. Your fourth grader may be moving into chapter books that are more complex in terms of character development, themes, and ideas. Below, we have included links to resources for online reading if you find you need more books.


Read Aloud
Research shows that reading aloud with your child is a powerful way to help them understand how stories and books work, think about big ideas and themes in literature, and learn new vocabulary. Reading aloud is also a wonderful way to spend time as a family!  We encourage all families to put time aside each day as read-aloud time.


Writing
Ideally, we would like fourth graders to write for about 20-30 minutes a day, five days a week. Again, we wish to maintain your child’s current writing skills, and this is best done through consistent, daily practice. Your child may write about anything he/she wishes—a topic he/she is interested in, a story about something that happened to him/her, a list of his/her favorite things - the possibilities are endless! A list of possible writing topics has also been included in the writing section below. Look through them and select ones that you feel would be most appropriate and engaging for your child. Encourage your child to apply what he/she knows about good writing at all times.


Writing topics for Third – Fifth Graders:

    
Do you have any siblings? Think about what it might mean to be a good brother or sister and write about it!
    
Make a list of questions to interview your parents or grandparents about what it was like when they were growing up as a kid. Then, ask them the questions and write about their answers!
    
You are in charge of writing a new radio show that is specifically made for kids to listen to! What topics do you have the announcers talk about? What music do you play? What products might you advertise?
    
Imagine if you are the principal of the school. What might you do differently? What things would you do that are the same? Write about it!
    
Every year over 8 billion plastic bottles and cans are thrown away. What are some things you can do to help encourage your family and friends to recycle?


Mathematics and Movement

    
Do jumping jacks as you count by twos from 20 to 100 and back from 100 to 20.
    
Do squats as you count by threes to 30 and back again.
    
Hop on one foot as you count by fours from 4 to 48 and back.
    
Do arm swings as you count by sixes from 6 to 72 and back.
    
Alternate counting with a friend or family member by sevens from 7 to 70 and back.
    
Jump forward and back as you count by eights from 8 to 80 and back.
    
Read the weight in grams of different food items in your kitchen.  Round the weights to the nearest 10 or 100 grams.
    
Read a recipe. What fractions does the recipe use? Double the fractions as if you were doubling the recipe.


Mathematics

    
Draw and label a floor plan of your house.
    
Time how long it takes you to do a specific chore, like making the bed. See if you can do it faster the next day.
    
Measure the perimeter of the room where you sleep in inches. Then calculate the area.
    
Go on a shape scavenger hunt. Find as many quadrilaterals in your neighborhood or house as you can.


Final Countdown (Grades 2-4)

Materials: 2 dice, 1 piece of paper for each player, a pencil for each player 

Directions for Grade 2:

(addition/subtraction)

    
Ask each player to write the number "99" at the top of their scratch paper.
    
Have the first player roll both dice and add them together to find the sum. 
    
Then, subtract the sum from their starting number of 99. After figuring out their result, they record the number remaining on their scratch paper. 
    
(For example: if they roll a 4 and 5, 4 + 5 = 9, 99 - 9 = 90. They would write 90.)
    
Have each player take a turn rolling the dice and computing their results.
    
The first player to get to zero wins!


Directions for Grades 3-4: (multiplication/subtraction)

    
Ask each player to write the number "399" at the top of their scratch paper.
    
Have the first player roll both dice and multiply them together to find the product. 
    
Then, subtract the product from their starting number of 399. After figuring out their result, they record the number remaining on their scratch paper. (For example: if they roll a 4 and 5, 4 x 5 = 20, 399 - 20 = 379. They would write 379.)
    
Have each player take a turn rolling the dice and computing their results.
    
The first player to get to zero wins!


Salute (Grades 1-5)

Materials: At least 3 players, a deck of cards (with the jacks, queens, kings, aces and jokers removed)

Directions:

Grades 1-2 will add; Grades 3-5 will multiply.

    
There will be two players and 1 judge.
    
Deal an equal number of cards face down to all three players.
    
Player 1 and Player 2 flip a card (without looking) and place it on their forehead facing each other.
    
The judge will say the product/sum of the two cards.
    
The first player to announce THEIR card takes both cards.
    
Rotate roles and continue.
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl17_divTabs_6","title":"Fifth Grade","content":"
Reading
We encourage all fifth-grade children to spend at least 30 minutes a day reading.  This time can be broken into smaller amounts if this works best for you and your child. In fifth grade, many of the books children are reading become more complex in terms of character development, themes, and ideas. Below, we have included links to resources for online reading if you find you need more books.

Read Aloud
Research shows that reading aloud with your child is a powerful way to help them understand how stories and books work, think about big ideas and themes in literature, and learn new vocabulary. Reading aloud is also a wonderful way to spend time as a family!  We encourage all families to put time aside each day as read-aloud time.

Writing
Ideally, we would like fifth graders to write for about 20-30 minutes a day, five days a week. Again, we wish to maintain your child’s current writing skills, and this is best done through consistent, daily practice. Your child may write about anything he/she wishes - a topic he/she is interested in, a story about something that happened to him/her, a list of his/her favorite things—the possibilities are endless! A list of possible writing topics has also been included in the writing section below. Look through them and select ones that you feel would be most appropriate and engaging for your child. Encourage your child to apply what he/she knows about good writing at all times.

Writing topics for Third – Fifth Graders:

    
Do you have any siblings? Think about what it might mean to be a good brother or sister and write about it!
    
Make a list of questions to interview your parents or grandparents about what it was like when they were growing up as a kid. Then, ask them the questions and write about their answers!
    
You are in charge of writing a new radio show that is specifically made for kids to listen to! What topics do you have the announcers talk about? What music do you play? What products might you advertise?
    
Imagine if you are the principal of the school. What might you do differently? What things would you do that are the same? Write about it!
    
Every year over 8 billion plastic bottles and cans are thrown away. What are some things you can do to help encourage your family and friends to recycle?


Mathematics and Movement

    
Do jumping jacks as you count by twos from 120 to 220 and back.
    
Do squats as you count by threes to 30 and back.
    
Hop on one foot as you count by fours from 4 to 48 and back.
    
Do arm swings as you count by sixes from 6 to 72 and back.
    
Alternate counting with a friend or family member by sevens from 7 to 70 and back.
    
Jump forward and back as you count by eights from 8 to 80 and back.
    
Read the weight in grams of different food items in your kitchen. Round the weights to the nearest 10 or 100 grams.
    
Read a recipe. What fractions does the recipe use? Double the fractions as if you were doubling the recipe.


Mathematics

    
Draw and label a floor plan of your house.
    
Measure the perimeter of the room where you sleep in inches. Then calculate the area.
    
Draw and label a floor plan of your dream tree house.


Addition and Multiplication Battle (Grades 1-5)

Materials:  a deck of playing cards (with the jacks, queens, kings, aces and jokers removed)



Directions:

    
 Deal an equal number of cards to each player.
    
Each player turns two cards over at a time.
    
Each player will state the sum / product of their two cards.
    
The player with the greatest sum / product gets the cards.
    
BATTLE: When sums are equivalent, turn 3 cards down and two up.

    a.	Each player will state the sum / product to determine who has the greater sum / product and will win the battle.
    
Play continues until one player has all the cards.
    
The player holding the cards at the end of the game wins.


Salute (Grades 1-5)

Materials: At least 3 players, a deck of cards (with the jacks, queens, kings, aces and jokers removed)

Directions:

Grades 1-2 will add; Grades 3-5 will multiply.

    
There will be two players and 1 judge.
    
Deal an equal number of cards face down to all three players.
    
Player 1 and Player 2 flip a card (without looking) and place it on their forehead facing each other.
    
The judge will say the product/sum of the two cards.
    
The first player to announce THEIR card takes both cards.
    
Rotate roles and continue.

tr.td: Looking for a good book? Check out this site with reviews and recommendations as well as sections devoted to popular book series.
Perfect for prereaders and beginning readers, this site takes a systematic phonics approach and combines it with phonemic awareness practice.
Check out this site for picture books and early reading books that can be narrated in both English and Spanish!
Listen to famous actors read books to students. There are also activity guides for each book. Videos are on Youtube or Vimeo.
Access over 400,000 resources including books, magazines, videos, podcast, test prep and more!
Students practice at their own pace, first filling in gaps in their understanding and then accelerating their learning.
